--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "jamietreetalker" <thequilldriver@...> wrote:
>
> Since the 70s, huh? I'm sorry, but I have to disagree. Well, maybe I've
> been imagining things for the past ten years, but there have been a host
> of researchers inventing real-time communication devices that produce
> some pretty convincing intelligent responses, or "EVP."
> 
> No disrespect intended, but do you really think that this scientist is
> an expert in EVP because he wrote a book that wasn't even picked up by a
> real publisher? That doesn't fly with people who have been doing this
> for ages and who have been producing exceptional results. A person can't
> just saunter into a field such as this with a Ph.D. and flash a book
> around claiming to know it all. In my humble opinion, this isn't a field
> that can be targeted for scientific research. There are too many
> variables to consider, most of which we know nothing about. It's nearly
> impossible to prove that EVP is real, scientifically or not, because
> there are always skeptics who will claim it's all fake. (And of course,
> everyone else knows better, right?)  I've read several journal articles
> and papers written by university professors and serious researchers, and
> from what I've learned, you can try as many times as you want to have a
> "controlled" environment for so-called "scientific" EVP research, but it
> will fail, over and over. You know why? The human element will
> interfere, whether it's during the experiment or afterward, every time.
> Now, I'm not saying your belief that this book is good is ridiculous
> because it must have value for you, or you wouldn't have posted it. I
> would like to point out, however, that you might consider a more open
> minded approach before waltzing into a group like this and insulting its
> population with your particular phraseology. We are all somewhat learned
> individuals, and we are particularly well-read in this field. Please do
> not assume we are unaware of anything.
> -Jamie
